title: Decision Theory and Rational Choice
description: Foundations of decision theory and how Active Inference provides a normative theory of decision making under uncertainty.
learning_objectives: Understand normative theories of decision making
Apply expected utility theory to decision problems
Connect decision theory to Active Inference

content.overview: Decision theory provides the normative foundation for rational choice under uncertainty. Active Inference extends decision theory by providing a principled account of how agents learn and represent their preferences.

subjective_expected_utility.bayesian_decision_theory: Decisions based on subjective expected utility

prospect_theory.value_function: v(x) = x^α for gains, -λ(-x)^β for losses
prospect_theory.probability_weighting: w(p) ≠ p - overweighting of small probabilities
prospect_theory.loss_aversion: λ > 1 - losses hurt more than gains help
prospect_theory.reference_dependence: Outcomes evaluated relative to reference point

active_inference_decision_making.expected_free_energy: G(π) = expected cost of policy π

bounded_rationality.satisficing: Good enough rather than optimal solutions

multi_agent_decision_theory.nash_equilibrium: No agent can improve by unilateral deviation

connections_to_active_inference.normative_theory: Expected free energy as generalization of expected utility

interactive_exercises.description: Calculate expected utility for decision problems

common_misconceptions.clarification: Behavioral economics shows systematic departures from rationality

common_misconceptions.misconception: Expected utility is the only rational theory
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference provides alternative normative accounts
Rational decision making works with uncertainty
